title: Life Masters' Individual by Edgar Kaplan
excerpt: Report on the prestigious Life Masters' Individual championship.

data.text:
**Life Masters' Individual**

by Edgar Kaplan

While I enthusiastically approve of the result of this year's Masters Individual, I can't say that I had a very good time playing in it. And I usually do. This is a nerve-shattering tourna­ment if you're in a good position to win: I could never relax and really en­joy the mad scramble. [Editor's note (by Moyse): It has, perhaps, been sub­tly indicated that Mr. Kaplan was the winner of this year's Masters Individ­ual, with its record-breaking field of 136, but we like to make everything pellucidly clear. He was.]

There are three factors in the winning of this event: you must play reasonably well; you need a lot of fortitude; and you must be continually lucky. Luck is the most important of the three, and in one about the individual.
